@Kito: There is no content that you can get on different web platforms than you can on the clearnet. Except for highly illegal things like CP or drug markets. Given that ZeroNet, like most other P2P software, is *not* an anonymization network, there's no reason for those things to be on here.

As for why one 'needs' zeronet, that varies. I think most people here are here for one of a few main reasons:

1. Want to take control over their own data. Major organizations are making this less and less so. Decentralized/P2P software like ZeroNet helps fight that.

2. Reduce reliance on major organizations. This one is mostly political/economic. You remove the ability of major organizations to control how you use the web, as you're no longer reliant on them.

3. Avoid censorship. This is what most chinese people are here for. To get around the filters/censorship their government forces on the internet.

4. Simply wanting to help develop new tech, and enjoying the decentralized web.

The main reasons to be here are *not* content. But do please enlighten me what other alternative web platforms you use explicitly for content you can't get elsewhere. AFAIK all you'd go for is CP and drugs. Since that's the only stuff not on clearnet.

@Kito: Well right off the bat there's NASA, ICANN, Google, DOD, etc. You can see just the organizations for the root servers [here.](https://www.iana.org/domains/root/servers) You can find quite a bit of info on [wikipedia.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_governance) And that's just for DNS and governing. For actual maintenance you've got your ISPs, and all the other hidden companies that you don't see that manage things. For just the web itself you need to look at things like host servers, namely stuff like IBM, amazon, etc.

Last I checked, the average person like your or me has *0* influence over these organizations and what they decide to do with the web. Which of us decided to make .google a tld? I certainly didn't. Who says you need to be an official registrar to register domain names? I didn't. Who agrees that a single organization (ICANN) gets to allocate and sell IP addresses? Not fucking me, that's for sure.

Are you comfortable with these companies essentially having 100% control over the internet and web? I personally don't. ZeroNet fixes that for the web side of things. cjdns/hyperboria fixes that for the IP side, and meshnets fix it for the hardware side. Once these systems are in place, you can have a truly free and distributed web uncontrolled by corporate/government goons.

Next time you use a clearnet site, do a bit of research. Install an extension to detect how many services are tracking you. Look at how many ads phone home to different major organziations. Then look at your network traffic. If you used a domain name, look at where it's coming from: your dns, their root server, etc. For your internet, look at your ISP, followed by who they peer with. If you spend money, watch that and see where it goes. It's horrifying.

If you're just looking for content, you're better off just using the clearnet. It's popular as fuck and has more and better content than any alternative can provide. I can't give you a personal reason to stick around zeronet. Personally, I use it because of these political issues. As well as the fact that I value my control over my own data. I also love the fact that it's distributed/decentralized and is completely resistant to any attackers. This means I'm safe to do as I please without worrying about anyone meddling. I also see it as the future of the internet and web, which is why I support it.

hubs are a special type of site that just explicitly hold data/content for special sites called 'merger sites'. ZeroMe is one such merger site, and has hubs to store the posts/profiles/etc. To add a hub, either just directly visit the address, or visit a profile that uses the hub and click "download hub".
@Deprekholia: They aren't communist lol. They *say* they're communist. In reality they're authoritarian and capitalistic.

@Sphinx: "The one thing that confused me ts that visiting a hub site for the first time, just gives the message " Please use ZeroMe to browse profiles on this page. " "

That means you directly visited the hub, which you shouldn't do unless you're just downloading it. You need to use ZeroMe to show the profiles/posts. The hubs by themselves do nothing.

"But now I added them all with http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Create+profile"

Noooooooo. Don't tell me you clicked "join hub" on all of them?! D: You might've just fucked up your profile big time. If they're on that page you already have them downloaded/added! Follow [my guide](/blog.kaffie.bit/?Post:25:How+to+change+your+ZeroMe+Hub&) on how to fix that.

"Hubs could be used for something like "subreddits"? If you don't add it you don't see the content?"

Correct. In fact, this has already been done over at [ZeroVoat](/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb/). Although multiple hubs/data sites haven't been added to the gui yet (it's done in the dev version of the site though). Different hub/data sites will hold different subreddits/channels, and then you can post in them.

" Merger Sites diplay content from Hubs. And users sync not only the merger site, but also partial contents from the hubs."

Users sync the whole hub. Unless the files are marked optional. But users don't need to have every hub. Just the ones they want to follow.

I feel like the patreon model is best. Fans can support their favorite creators spending as much as they'd like either recurring or not. No need for ads. And everything created can be released publicly free/foss/etc. Likewise it allows creators to spend more time working on something even if it may not be released right away, and still have funding nonetheless. Good for projects that might take a while. Many small donations leads to decent pay where fans only pay a little.

@Realjohndoe: Keep in mind that using the tor browser on zeronet doesn't really help much. It would only anonymize any clearnet links. Since everything else is a local file on your computer. Instead you have to configure the ZN client itself to use tor.

@caryoscelus: with pateron people can "subscribe" to automatically regularly give donations, and in some cases get early access to content (which is released for everyone else later). Patreon also allows people to just do a 1-time donation. Ultimately I find it to be best as a subscription donation model which patreon is focused on helps provide a consistent income while also allowing work to be public (either right away, or after a delay). There's also options for "goals", ie "$x/month and we'll do Y" which helps incentivize donations. Ofc you don't need patreon to have this model, but patreon just makes it really easy to set up. Manual donations don't have automatic monthly donations (putting on the burden on the fan, rather than on the payment processor). For comparison, I had some bulk donations through bitcoin one or two times, but I get a regular small payment from patreon each month. Makes patreon overall the better option. 1-time donations always seem a bit weird at really low $ amounts like $1-2, but with a monthly thing it's a lot more normal. Perhaps that's just my perception of it though. Very flexible while also encouraging regular small donations, and having a flexible reward system and larger goals for your base. A simple donation button doesn't do any of that and tends to encourage fewer but larger donations (leading to less overall). That's been my experience doing both methods. 

I think brave's model could end up doing well as well. Having automatic donations to visited sites/channels/etc so the donation amount is based on how much you view the content. But I don't have experience with that one.

@Ansho Rei: As it stands, each zeronet site already has a bitcoin address, which is the address of the site. And there's a donate button in the sidebar. I've actually received donations in this manner, which was a little weird but it actually worked. Same goes for your zeroid account (as you have a public key and private key which indeed are bitcoin addresses). If brave's cryptocurrency uses the same address algorithm, then they should work as brave addresses as well which would make it easy to implement on brave's end. Might be worth asking them about.
